The integral will be of the standard form if $x$ were $y$ and if for $y$ were $x$. It can be seen that ordinates must represent $h$ and abscissas lengths, and hence the table for plotting reads  

\[ 
\begin{array}{ccc} 
\text{y} & 6.34 & 4.21 \ 
\text{x} & 124 & 336 \ 
\end{array} 
\]
Plotting these values and therefore construct the sum curve (see Fig. 30), we find the last ordinate to be $2.75$, and this is the value of $\int_0^4 f(dy)$.

At an earlier stage in the 18th of the above loading is given, when the shear at every point in the span (say form a beam loaded in any way) the load may be given as a function of it, $f(x)$ as given below.

blocks.latex:
M = \int_a^b f(x) \; dx 
\Rightarrow M = \left[ f(x) \right]_{a}^{b} = f(b) - f(a) \; .
blocks.description: This equation represents the bending moment as a function of the load, integrating the load function over a specified interval [a, b].

blocks.text: In the majority of cases, when the loading is given, the bending moment can be derived by the same integration formulas by inserting the notations provided.

blocks.description: This equation relates the derivative of the bending moment to the derivative of the load function.

blocks.text: Here, the two expressions will represent the statements in the notation of the calculus; $M = \int \,( -f\, dx)$ being termed as $M = f \left[ \int f(x) \right]$.
If the loading is not uniform, but continuous, the summation must be performed graphically.
(The link polygon method largely used allows that these curves, e.g., the linking polygon for the loads gives at once the curve of bending moment).
